awd_titl_txt: CAREER: New Learning-based Algorithms for the Analysis of Very-Large-Scale Neuroimaging Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial intelligence, fueled by recent advances in machine learning, is poised to transform healthcare and biomedical research. Machine learning algorithms allow researchers to analyze complex patterns in large datasets, in the service of advancing our understanding of biological mechanisms and developing clinical tools. This project considers very large scale brain imaging studies, including, for example, tens of thousands of individuals contributing head MRI scans and other biomedical data such as whole-genome sequences or clinical records. Such data allow researchers to map the effects of genetic, environmental, and other factors on the structure and function of the brain, which in turn advances our knowledge of disorders like Alzheimer's. Today, the primary obstacle in exploiting very large scale brain imaging datasets is computational, because existing software tools don't scale well and lack in quality assurance capabilities. This project will produce a machine-learning based computational pipeline that will fill this gap. In the largest study of its kind, we will showcase the developed software tools to chart the heritability of shapes of brain structures.  In addition, the project will implement a diverse set of educational outreach initiatives, such as a customized research experience for under-represented minority high-school students.   

Neuroimaging is entering a new era of unprecedented scale and complexity. Soon, we will have datasets including more than 100,000 individuals. The fundamental challenge in analyzing and exploiting these data is computational. Today, widely-used neuroimage analysis tools are computationally demanding, produce results that are sensitive to confounds, and are limited in quality control capabilities, making them infeasible at scale. This project will extend recent advances in machine learning to develop an innovative computational pipeline that addresses the drawbacks of existing methods. First, a computationally efficient and flexible brain MRI segmentation framework will be developed that integrates rich neuroanatomical prior models. The segmentation tool will be made robust to confounding effects such as subject motion via the use of an adversarial learning strategy. Learning-based methods will be further investigated to obviate the time-consuming manual quality control of segmentations. Finally, an innovative metric learning approach will be used to study genetic influences on brain morphology in the UK Biobank. The project will also implement an integrated educational plan that is focused on interdisciplinary, hands-on and lifelong learning. The researchers will devote significant effort to developing core educational material that will be adapted and utilized for audiences of various backgrounds and stages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Advancing AI for Medical Imaging and Healthcare

This NSF CAREER project has made significant contributions to artificial intelligence (AI) in medical imaging, with a focus on improving brain MRI analysis, developing interpretable AI models, and ensuring that machine learning tools can be used in real-world healthcare settings. Through this work, we have helped bridge the gap between AI research, biomedical science, and clinical practice, paving the way for more effective and trustworthy AI-driven healthcare solutions.

Intellectual Merit: Innovations in AI for Medical Imaging

Over the course of this project, we developed several state-of-the-art AI tools that have improved the way medical images are analyzed:

  • KeyMorph: A novel AI-powered tool for MRI registration that enables faster and more accurate alignment of medical images. 
  • Neural Pre-Processing (NPP): An advanced preprocessing pipeline for brain MRI scans, ensuring consistency across imaging datasets by automatically handling skull-stripping, intensity normalization, and spatial alignment.
  • Generalized Prevalence Adjustment (GPA) and Conditional Prevalence Adjustment (CoPA): Two cutting-edge methods that address bias and confounding factors in AI models, improving robustness and reliability in large-scale medical imaging studies.
  • PaIRNet: A deep learning model for analyzing longitudinal medical imaging data, helping track disease progression in neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s.

These innovations have pushed the boundaries of AI in neuroimaging, enabling researchers and clinicians to process medical images more efficiently, detect diseases earlier, and reduce human error in medical diagnosis.

Broader Impacts: AI for Healthcare, Education, and Society

This project has had a far-reaching impact beyond the research lab, improving healthcare outcomes, education, and workforce development in the field of AI-driven medicine.

1. Advancing Healthcare and Patient Care

By making our AI models publicly available, we have helped hospitals, medical researchers, and clinicians integrate AI into their imaging workflows. Tools like KeyMorph and NPP are being used to enhance disease diagnosis, track neurological disorders, and improve personalized treatment planning.

2. Training the Next Generation of AI and Medical Imaging Experts

This project has played a key role in education and workforce development, providing students and researchers with hands-on training in AI for medical imaging:

  • Created graduate-level courses on Machine Learning with Biomedical Data and Interpretable AI at Cornell, giving students real-world experience in AI-driven healthcare applications.
  • Hosted the Machine Learning in Medicine webinar series, engaging hundreds of students, clinicians, and AI researchers worldwide.
  • Mentored multiple graduate and undergraduate students, many of whom have gone on to publish research papers, present at international conferences, and pursue careers in AI and biomedical sciences.

3. Open Science and AI Ethics

To ensure ethical and trustworthy AI, this project has addressed contributed to the development of robust machine learning algorithms in medicine. Our GPA and CoPA methods have improved model robustness and generalizability, ensuring AI tools perform well across diverse patient populations and imaging datasets.

Additionally, we have contributed to the MELBA open-access journal, promoting transparency and reproducibility in AI-driven medical research.

Lasting Impact and Future Directions

By developing and freely distributing AI tools, advancing ethical AI in medicine, and training the next generation of researchers, this project has laid the foundation for future breakthroughs in AI-driven healthcare.

  • Moving forward, we aim to:
  • Expand KeyMorph to other medical imaging applications, including oncology, cardiology, and radiology.
  • Improve AI bias mitigation techniques to ensure robust and ethical healthcare AI solutions.
  • Continue mentoring students and developing AI educational resources to prepare the future biomedical AI workforce.

Through this work, we hope to revolutionize medical imaging, improve healthcare outcomes, and ensure AI technologies benefit society as a whole.

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2025
Modified by: Mert R Sabuncu
